folders.Book 1 - Lord of the Trinity Star: Book 1 - Lord of the Trinity Star

A Falling Star's Memories.name: A Falling Star's Memories
A Falling Star's Memories.descriptionHazard: The shaft walls vanish and are replaced by an endless field of stars in all direction, as if the viewer were suddenly lost in outer space.
A Falling Star's Memories.disable: @Check[arcana|dc:40] (master) to unweave the magic left in the wake of the Trinity Star's passage, @Check[thievery|dc:43] (expert) to etch temporary runes to siphon away the magic, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (8th rank; counteract DC 33) to counteract the magic; three successes are required to disable the trap. Once the PCs are within the trap's overwhelming illusion, they can still attempt these checks to disable it, but the check DCs increase by 2.
A Falling Star's Memories.routine:
A Voyage Through the Infinite (1 action) Every round on its turn, the trap inflicts all creatures in the shaft with the perception that they have been hurtling at an unimaginable speed through the vastness of space. The stars are so distant that no indication of movement can be observed or felt beyond that overwhelming mental conviction. At the same time, the creatures feel as if something unimaginably powerful and hungry is chasing them... and gaining on them. Any PC who looks over their shoulder sees that the stars are indeed winking out behind them, as if an immense black object were growing closer or as if the stars themselves were vanishing. While the PC's body is somehow protected by the vastness of space, their minds are not—each PC must attempt a @Check[will|dc:40] save.

Critical Success As success below, but the creature also realizes they're reliving the memories of Runelord Xanderghul—like him, they're escaping some sort of horrific fate and are hurtling toward Golarion. The next time this creature achieves a critical success against this trap, they suddenly see Golarion loom large, and as they witness their "crash" into the Throne of the Troll King, they suddenly wake, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}, in area C1 at the heart Xin-Cyrusian. If any other PCs are still trapped in the Falling Star's Memories, a PC in Xin-Cyrusian knows instinctively that they can call out to those trapped PCs—each PC in Xin-Cyrusian who does so reduces the save DC against A Voyage Through the Infinite for those still trapped by 5.

Success The creature realizes they're experiencing the path the Trinity Star took through the cosmos and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The creature's grip on reality fades as they experience what seems like years or even decades of hurtling adrift through a vast expanse. The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 24 hours or increases the value of their stupefied condition by 1 if they're already stupefied.

Critical Failure As failure, but @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} (or increase the stupefied condition by 2).

Special If this trap would cause a creature's stupefied condition to exceed @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 5}, the creature instead "crashes" to the ground on the hilltop outside, about ten feet from the Throne of the Troll King. The creature takes @Damage[10d6[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic] save), and their stupefied condition now has an unlimited duration.

action->Moment of Glory.name: Moment of Glory
action->Moment of Glory.description:
Trigger A creature moves (or falls) more than 60 feet down the shaft below the illusory throne

Effect All creatures in the shaft suddenly witness an endless night sky all around them, as if they were hurtling through outer space with no sign of any nearby planetary bodies. Each affected creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:40] save to resist being @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} on a critical failure) for 24 hours as the visual overwhelms them. The trap then rolls initiative.

action->Adaptive Rune Magic.name: Adaptive Rune Magic
action->Adaptive Rune Magic.description:
Frequency once per round

Trigger Aethusa Casts a Spell of 6th rank or higher

Effect Aethusa momentarily infuses her preferred form of sin magic (sloth) with the power of either gluttony or greed magic. The triggering spell slot is expended, but instead of the spell's normal effects, Aethusa casts either @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.dN8QBNuTiaBHCKUe]{Cursed Metamorphosis} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.fd31tAHSSGXyOxW6]{Vampiric Exsanguination} at 6th rank.

action->Past Lives.name: Past Lives
action->Past Lives.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect Aethusa accesses what she believes to be the memories of two previous runelords. For the next 1 minute, whenever Aethusa makes a skill check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge}, she rolls three times and uses the highest result.

action->Quickened Casting.name: Quickened Casting
action->Quickened Casting.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect If Aethusa's next action is to cast a cantrip or a spell that is 6th rank or lower, reduce the number of actions to cast it by 1 (minimum 1 action).

action->Steady Spellcasting.name: Steady Spellcasting
action->Steady Spellcasting.description: If a reaction would disrupt Aethusa's spellcasting action, she attempts a @Check[flat|dc:15]. On a success, the action isn't disrupted.

Aethusa's Prison.name: Aethusa's Prison
Aethusa's Prison.descriptionHazard: A roiling sphere of chromatic energy floats above a pedestal marked with arcane symbols.
Aethusa's Prison.disable: @Check[nature|dc:42] (legendary) or @Check[crafting|dc:45] (master) to remove an immunity the prison currently has to one of the following damage types: acid, cold, electricity, or fire (this effect lasts until the prison uses its Energy Immunity reaction to regain that immunity); @Check[arcana|dc:42] (master) to fortify the pedestal's containment runes, preventing the prison from using its Chromatic Eruption action for 1 round and causing it to suffer feedback that inflicts @Damage[20[untyped]] damage (this damage bypasses the prison's hardness and immunities); @Check[thievery|dc:42] (master) or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (8th rank; counteract DC 34) to suppress the pedestal's containment runes for 1 round, preventing the prison from using its Self-Repair action and causing it to suffer feedback that inflicts @Damage[20[untyped]] damage (this damage bypasses the prison's hardness and immunities). Unlike most hazards, Aethusa's prison can't be disabled, but it can be destroyed by reducing it to 0 Hit Points.
Aethusa's Prison.reset: The trap deactivates and then resets automatically when it repairs to its maximum Hit Points.
Aethusa's Prison.routine: (2 actions) The prison uses its first action to Self-Repair. If the hazard has less than its maximum Hit Points, it then uses its Chromatic Eruption action.

action->Lockdown Protocol.name: Lockdown Protocol
action->Lockdown Protocol.description:
Trigger The prison takes any damage

Effect The prison uses its Chromatic Eruption action as part of this reaction, then gains immunity to the triggering damage type until the hazard resets. The hazard then rolls initiative.

action->Self-Repair.name: Self-Repair
action->Self-Repair.description: The prison regains @Damage[30[healing]] Hit Points. Then, if the prison is at maximum Hit Points, the hazard deactivates and immediately resets.

action->Chromatic Eruption.name: Chromatic Eruption
action->Chromatic Eruption.description:
Requirements The prison has less than its maximum Hit Points

Effect Tendrils of uncontained magical energy lash at creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20], dealing @Damage[10d6[untyped]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:37|basic] save) of a randomly determined type. Roll [[/gmr 1d4]]: 1–acid, 2–cold, 3–electricity, 4–fire.

action->Energy Immunity.name: Energy Immunity
action->Energy Immunity.description:
Trigger The prison takes acid, cold, electricity, or fire damage

Effect The prison takes the damage but then gains immunity to the triggering damage type until the hazard resets.

Animate Nightmare.name: Animate Nightmare
Animate Nightmare.publicNotes:
Whereas animate dreams form from the fears of specific individuals, animate nightmares are spawned by the terrors that beset civilizations. An animate nightmare's appearance depends on the type of fear that created it, but, like fears, result in similar forms.

Emigrants From Dreams

Animate nightmares often haunt the ruins of the civilization that birthed them. Others are drawn to Jandelay, the enigmatic demiplane where the fragments of dead worlds are preserved for all eternity, or to Abaddon, where apocalyptic nihilism is the rule. These latter nightmares might stay close to their "parent" civilizations, while others wander the broken avenues of multiple worlds, feeding off the traces of fear that linger in those places.
Animate Nightmare.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Apocalyptic Embodiment.name: Apocalyptic Embodiment
action->Apocalyptic Embodiment.description:
An animate nightmare embodies one societal fear, chosen from the following options. Depending on the choice, the animate nightmare gains one additional 8th-rank occult innate spell, as listed below.

Disaster The animate nightmare appears as a person or creature who's suffered devastating wounds from a calamity—horrific burns, crushed and broken limbs, impalements from wind-tossed debris, and the like. It gains @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0XP2XOxT9VSiXFDr]{Phantasmal Calamity} at 8th rank.

Disorder The animate nightmare looks like a distorted parody of a commonplace person with unnaturally long limbs, a twisted visage, and a scratching shrill voice. It gains @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.LiGbewa9pO0yjbsY]{Confusion} at 8th rank.

Famine The animate nightmare appears as a humanoid carrion bird or other bestial scavenger (such as a jackal or a fly) on the brink of death from starvation. It gains @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.fd31tAHSSGXyOxW6]{Vampiric Exsanguination} at 8th rank.

Plague The animate nightmare is shaped like a tangle of diseased bodies animated into hideous life that might have just crawled out of a mass grave. It gains @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.MS60WhVifb45qORJ]{Spiritual Epidemic} at 8th rank.

action->Panicking Touch.name: Panicking Touch
action->Panicking Touch.description:
Requirements The animate nightmare's previous action was a nightmare tendril Strike against a creature

Effect The animate nightmare's touch lingers and infuses the mind of the creature it just attempted to Strike. The creature takes @Damage[8d6[persistent,mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:38|basic] save). If the creature is already taking persistent mental damage from Panicking Touch, it must instead succeed at a @Check[will|dc:38] save or endure a different effect based on the animate nightmare's apocalyptic embodiment; this additional effect lasts as long as the persistent mental damage lasts.

Disaster The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and can't reduce its frightened condition.

Disorder The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused}.

Famine The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1}.

Plague The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1}.

Apocalypse Stormfront.name: Apocalypse Stormfront
Apocalypse Stormfront.descriptionHazard: An endless void stretches in all directions. Visions of Golarion's destruction roll like storm clouds across the space.
Apocalypse Stormfront.disable: @Check[acrobatics|dc:47] to Fly through the space without becoming stuck in the webs, @Check[athletics|dc:50] to Climb the webs and make progress forward through the infinite, @Check[nature|dc:47] or @Check[occultism|dc:47] or @Check[arcana|dc:50] or @Check[religion|dc:50] (legendary) to collapse the extradimensional space, or @Check[perception|dc:52] to peer through the visions of Golarion to notice discrepancies that help keep the overwhelming despair from setting in; six successes disables the hazard, causing it to vanish forever and shunting all creatures to Liralarue's Prison.
Apocalypse Stormfront.reset: The hazard resets automatically once no creatures are in the area.
Apocalypse Stormfront.routine:
(1 action) (arcane, emotion, illusion, mental) A stormfront filled with illusory scenes of Golarion's destruction rolls through the extradimensional space. Each creature in the hazard's area takes @Damage[6d12[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:42|basic|traits:arcane,emotion,illusion,mental] save). On a failed save, a creature is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 2} on a critical failure). A PC reduced to 0 Hit Points by this damage is shunted back into area C7.

A creature that takes damage while Climbing the webs must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save or fall. A creature can try to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY]{Grab an Edge} (@Check[reflex|dc:40]). On a success, they lose one success they've earned to escape the hazard but otherwise arrest their fall. On a failure, they plummet into the void, losing all Athletics successes they've earned to escape the hazard. Each round on their turn, the character can try to Grab an Edge again, but each time they fail to do so, the party must earn an additional success to escape the hazard. Characters who fall @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} or repeatedly fail to Grab an Edge might effectively become lost in the void, though once the nightmare hazard is disabled, they appear along with the rest of the PCs in Liralarue's Prison.

action->Brewing Storm.name: Brewing Storm
action->Brewing Storm.description:
Trigger A creature enters the shaft leading to area C8

Effect Storm clouds roiling with gouts of fire, bolts of lightning, and the wails of uncountable souls form in the distance. The hazard then rolls initiative.

Ayavah.name: Ayavah
Ayavah.allSavesBonus: +1 status to saves against spells and magic effects

equipment->Crafter's Eyepiece (Greater).name: Crafter's Eyepiece (Greater)
equipment->Crafter's Eyepiece (Greater).description:
This rugged metal eyepiece etched with square patterns is designed to be worn over a single eye. Twisting the lens reveals a faint three-dimensional outline of an item you plan to build or repair, with helpful labels on the component parts.

You gain a +2 item bonus to Crafting checks. When you Repair an item, increase the Hit Points restored to 10 + 10 per proficiency rank on a success or 15 + 15 per proficiency rank on a critical success.

Activate—Prototype 1 minute (manipulate)

Frequency once per day

Effect You calibrate the eyepiece to have it cast a 5th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.TUj8eugNqAvB1vVR]{Creation} spell over the course of 1 minute to construct a temporary item.

equipment->Masquerade Scarf (Greater).name: Masquerade Scarf (Greater)
equipment->Masquerade Scarf (Greater).description:
This delicately embroidered scarf matches with every outfit and can even complete a costume or disguise with illusions.

Activate—Masquerade 2 (manipulate)

Effect You arrange the scarf over your lower face, and it casts a 2nd-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.i35dpZFI7jZcRoBo]{Illusory Disguise} spell on you, which ends immediately if the scarf is removed. You can alter the scarf's appearance or make it invisible as part of the illusory disguise, but it can still be felt if touched.

equipment->Shining Symbol (Greater).name: Shining Symbol (Greater)
equipment->Shining Symbol (Greater).description:
If you worship a deity, this golden amulet transforms into your deity's religious symbol when you invest it. You gain a +2 item bonus to Religion. The symbol casts dim light in a @Template[emanation|distance:20].

Activate—Spiritual Light 2 (concentrate, light, revelation)

Frequency once per day

Effect The light cast by the symbol becomes bright light for 10 minutes and shines through bodies to reveal hints of the spirits within. Creatures in the light receive a –2 status penalty to Deception and Stealth checks, and while it's active your enemies in the light gain weakness 5 to spirit damage.

You can Dismiss this activation.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-effects.Item.NNxguHneoM3NvW1S]{Aura: Shining Symbol}

Craft Requirements You must be holy or unholy.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Bloodline Focus.name: Bloodline Focus
action->Bloodline Focus.description: When Ayavah Refocuses, she completely fills her focus pool.

action->Corruption of Sin.name: Corruption of Sin
action->Corruption of Sin.description: When Ayavah casts a bloodline spell using a Focus Point or one of the following spells: blister, disintegrate, divine wrath, enlarge, fear, or slow, she can choose to either give a target a –1 status penalty to AC for 1 round or gain a +2 status bonus to Intimidation checks for 1 round.

action->Legendary Sculptor.name: Legendary Sculptor
action->Legendary Sculptor.description: Ayavah makes Crafting checks associated with sculpture at legendary proficiency. If she rolls a failure on a Crafting check involving sculpture, she gets a success instead.

action->Reach Spell.name: Reach Spell
action->Reach Spell.description: If the next action Ayavah takes is to Cast a Spell that has a range, increase that spell's range by 30 feet.

Baolen.name: Baolen
Baolen.publicNotes: A kraken is an enormous, squid-like leviathan with a cruel intelligence. It hunts ships, whales, and heroes alike. The hatred and envy krakens hold for alghollthus, their rivals, has led many krakens to make their lairs in sunken cities, where they can sift through ancient lore and uncover long-lost arcane secrets.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The creature ends one condition affecting it.

action->Altered Weather.name: Altered Weather
action->Altered Weather.description:
A kraken reshapes the weather within 2 miles of it, with the effect of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.XkDCzMIyc0YOjw05]{Control Weather} ritual centered on the kraken and based on its emotional state, at the GM's discretion. If the kraken dies, the weather returns to normal immediately.

Baolen is currently content in his place as an object of worship, though, so the surrounding weather remains calm.

action->Susceptible to Confusion.name: Susceptible to Confusion
action->Susceptible to Confusion.description: Baolen's mythic resilience doesn't apply to Will saving throws he makes against the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} condition. If Baolen starts his turn confused, he takes @Damage[6d10[mental]] damage.

action->Undying Myth.name: Undying Myth
action->Undying Myth.description:
Cost all of Baolen's Mythic Points

Trigger Baolen would die and has at least 1 Mythic Point

Effect Baolen remains standing and conscious, and recovers 50% of his maximum Hit Points.

action->Constrict.name: Constrict
action->Constrict.description:
@Damage[(2d10+17)[bludgeoning]], @Check[fortitude|dc:40|basic]. On a failed save, a creature that is holding its breath loses [[/gmr 1d4 #Lost rounds of air from Constrict]]{1d4 rounds} worth of air.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Constrict]

action->Curse of Flawed History.name: Curse of Flawed History
action->Curse of Flawed History.description:
Saving Throw @Check[will|dc:37]

Effect The target struggles to differentiate between alternate histories and how the past truly occurred. The creature takes a –2 status penalty to checks made to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} (or a –4 penalty on a critical failure). This curse has an unlimited duration.

action->Double Attack.name: Double Attack
action->Double Attack.description:
The kraken makes two Strikes with two different arms or tentacles, each limb targeting a different creature. Double Attack counts as two attacks toward the kraken's multiple attack penalty, but the penalty doesn't increase until after both attacks are made.

If the kraken subsequently uses the Grab action, it Grabs any number of creatures it hit with Double Attack.

action->Ink Cloud.name: Ink Cloud
action->Ink Cloud.description:
The kraken releases a cloud of black, venomous ink in an @Template[emanation|distance:80]. This cloud has no effect outside water.

Creatures inside the ink cloud are exposed to retrocognitive ink poison and are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VRSef5y1LmL2Hkjf]{Undetected} while inside the cloud.

The kraken can't use Ink Cloud again for [[/br 2d6 #Recharge Ink Cloud]]{2d6 rounds}, and the cloud dissipates after 1 minute.

action->Jet.name: Jet
action->Jet.description: The kraken moves through the water up to 280 feet in a straight line without triggering reactions.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Baolen regains an expended spell.

action->Retrocognitive Ink.name: Retrocognitive Ink
action->Retrocognitive Ink.description:
Baolen is immune to this poison

Saving Throw @Check[will|dc:40]

Maximum Duration 10 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[5d6[mental]] damage, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2}, and the target is exposed to the curse of flawed history (1 round)

Bittersweet Mask.name: Bittersweet Mask
Bittersweet Mask.descriptionHazard: The many iron bars of this iron mask fits tightly around Javownir's head and snout, looking almost as if it was built in place to conform specifically to the shape of his skull with no apparent latch or hinge for it to be removed.
Bittersweet Mask.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:45] (expert) twice to find the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} latches, @Check[athletics|dc:48] (master) to wrench the mask open quickly enough to prevent it from triggering before it's destroyed, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (9th-rank; counteract DC 35), or automatic with Spleen's key
Bittersweet Mask.reset: The mask resets automatically at the start of the round after it is triggered.

action->Linked to Javownir.name: Linked to Javownir
action->Linked to Javownir.description: Whenever the mask takes damage, Javownir takes the same damage (@Check[reflex|dc:44|basic] save)

action->Toxic Off-gassing.name: Toxic Off-gassing
action->Toxic Off-gassing.description:
Trigger The mask takes damage, or an Athletics check to wrench it free fails or critically fails

Effect The mask creates a cloud of poison gas in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] around Javownir. Creatures in the area take @Damage[(6d12+41)[poison]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:44|basic] save; Javownir treats the result of this save as one degree of success worse than the rolled result).

action->Coven.name: Coven
action->Coven.description:
A Bittersweet Sister adds @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.r784cIz17eWujtQj]{Scrying}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.PHVHBbdHeQRfjLmE]{Spirit Blast} to her coven's spells.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Coven]

action->Moonlight's Kiss.name: Moonlight's Kiss
action->Moonlight's Kiss.description:
A moon hag in an area illuminated by moonlight gains a +2 status bonus to AC and initiative rolls. In the light of a full moon, they're @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened}, and can use the extra action only to Stride or Strike. If the moon hag has a fly Speed, they can use the extra action to Fly as well.

Any time they're outside of the oubliette or in area C7 they are in moonlight.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description:
The moon hag can take on the appearance of any Medium humanoid woman. This doesn't change their Speed or their attack and damage bonuses with their Strikes, but it might change the damage type their Strikes deal (typically to bludgeoning).

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

action->Dreadful Prediction.name: Dreadful Prediction
action->Dreadful Prediction.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The moon hag howls a series of dreadful, apocalyptic predictions at a single creature within 30 feet, shattering its perceptions of reality. The target must attempt a @Check[will|dc:38] save and takes a –2 circumstance penalty to the save if it can see the moon. On a failure, the creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 3} on a critical failure) until the curse is removed. Regardless of the outcome, the creature is then temporarily immune for 24 hours.

action->Ride the Moonbeams.name: Ride the Moonbeams
action->Ride the Moonbeams.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The moon hag teleports themself and any items they're wearing and holding to another space within 30 feet, or 60 feet if they're in moonlight. They then gain a 25-foot fly Speed until the end of their next turn. If the moon hag is in the air when the effect ends, they float to the ground, taking no falling damage.

Any time they're outside of the oubliette or in area C7 they are in moonlight.

Clockwork Whale.name: Clockwork Whale
Clockwork Whale.publicNotes:
Out of all ancient Azlant's clockwork creations, clockwork whales are perhaps the most impressive—or at least the among the largest. Shaped like a bizarre fusion of a shark and an enormous toothed whale, clockwork whales patrolled the shipping lanes around Azlant for centuries before Earthfall shattered the continent, sinking it beneath the waves. Outfitted with complex programming and sensory arrays that allowed for near-perfect navigation, clockwork whales are thought to have been used primarily for securing new and safe nautical routes, although some served as naval transports during Azlant's cold war with the empire's ancient enemy, the alghollthus.

With jaws nearly a third of its entire length, a clockwork whale's bite can slice neatly through smaller seafaring vessels and inflict devastating damage to the hulls of larger ones. These gears swiftly cut those swallowed whole into fragments that are then slowly washed away by the flow of water through tiny gaps in the creature's body.

Winding Up

Most clockworks must be wound with a unique key by another creature. This takes 1 minute, after which the clockwork remains operational for the listed amount of time. As long as a clockwork whale spends at least a minute every day swimming, its self-winding ability allows it to continue operating without needing this step. A clockwork whale that can't swim (as might be the case after a clockwork whale becomes beached) usually remains operational for approximately 8 hours before it completely winds down.

action->Aquatic Echolocation.name: Aquatic Echolocation
action->Aquatic Echolocation.description: The clockwork whale can use its hearing as a precise sense at the listed range, but only underwater.

action->Astounding Orienteering.name: Astounding Orienteering
action->Astounding Orienteering.description: While in a large body of water, the clockwork whale treats a failure at Survival checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.fJImDBQfqfjKJOhk]{Sense Direction} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EA5vuSgJfiHH7plD]{Track} as a success.

action->Self-Winding.name: Self-Winding
action->Self-Winding.description: A clockwork whale winds itself through the act of swimming, and as long as it spends at least a minute a day swimming, it gains 24 hours of operational time. A creature can still attempt a @Check[thievery|dc:36] check to Disable a Device to cause the clockwork whale to lose 1 hour of operational time (or 2 hours on a critical success).

action->Gearsong.name: Gearsong
action->Gearsong.description: The whale creates a vocalization that can be heard up to 1 mile away, or 10 miles away underwater. Creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] (or a @Template[type:emanation|distance:60] underwater) take @Damage[15d6[sonic]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:38|basic] save). On a failed save, a creature is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 3} on a critical failure). The whale can't use Gearsong again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Gearsong]]{1d4 rounds}.

Covetous Corridor.name: Covetous Corridor
Covetous Corridor.descriptionHazard: Statues depicting the runelords of envy steal magic from intruders.
Covetous Corridor.disable: @Check[arcana|dc:45] (master) to unweave the magic surrounding a statue, @Check[athletics|dc:48] (expert) to wrest a statue's implement from its hands, @Check[thievery|dc:48] (expert) to slip an implement free, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (9th rank; counteract DC 36) to counteract the magic that empowers the statue. Increase the DCs to disable the Belimarius statue by 2. Each statue must be disabled or counteracted separately, and disabling the Belimarius statue or all nine other statues permanently disables the hazard.
Covetous Corridor.reset: The hazard resets automatically if not disabled.
Covetous Corridor.routine: (4 actions) The hazard uses @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.RDXXE7wMrSPCLv5k]{Steal} Magic twice. Once the implements of at least three runelord statues are charged, the hazard uses its next available action to Transfer Magic. If the hazard starts its turn with the Belimarius statue charged, the hazard uses its reaction to Empower Barrier. A disabled runelord statue can't use Steal Magic. If the Belimarius statue is disabled, the hazard can't use Transfer Magic or Empower Barrier.

action->Covet Magic.name: Covet Magic
action->Covet Magic.description:
Trigger A magic item or active spell effect enters the corridor

Effect A randomly determined statue uses the hazard's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.RDXXE7wMrSPCLv5k]{Steal} Magic action. The hazard then rolls initiative.

action->Steal Magic.name: Steal Magic
action->Steal Magic.description:
Roll a [[/gmr d10]] to determine which statue activates, rerolling a result of 10 or any result that would indicate a disabled statue or a statue that is already charged. The indicated statue casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.kUSShxXzY1sPtJA0]{Detonate Magic} with a [[/gmr 1d20+32 #Counteract]]{+32} bonus to its counteract check. The spell targets the closest magic item within 120 feet, prioritizing the highest-ranking magic item and targeting spell effects only if no magic item is within range. On a success or critical success, the statue gathers the dispersed energy into its implement, charging it.

While the statue's implement remains charged, any creature who is at least an expert in @Check[arcana|dc:44], @Check[nature|dc:44], @Check[occultism|dc:44], or @Check[religion|dc:44] can use a 2-action activity with the concentrate trait to attempt a DC 44 check using that skill. On a success or critical success, they return the magic to its original source, causing it to reactivate. Removing an implement from its statue prevents the statue from using Transfer Magic but doesn't prevent a creature from restoring the charge to its source.

action->Transfer Magic.name: Transfer Magic
action->Transfer Magic.description:
Requirements The implements of at least three runelord statues are charged

Effect Three statues with charged implements transfer their charges to the Belimarius statue. While the Belimarius statue holds at least one charge, a creature can transfer charges from its implement as described in Steal Magic, except the DC of the skill check increases to DC 46; success returns the stolen magic to the appropriate items.

@Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]

action->Empower Barrier.name: Empower Barrier
action->Empower Barrier.description:
Requirements The hazard starts its turn, and the Belimarius statue holds at least one charge

Effect The Belimarius statue transfers all charges from its implement into the force barrier separating the corridor from area B3. For every charge the statue transfers, the force barrier gains 10 temporary Hit Points that last for 1 hour. (If the force barrier has been destroyed, the statue instead expends the first charge to cast a 6th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force}, with any remaining charges granting the barrier temporary Hit Points.) Charges transferred to the force barrier are lost forever and can't be returned to items they were stolen from.

Czaresia.name: Czaresia
Czaresia.publicNotes:
Rune giants are tyrants among their own kind, given power to command and magically control other giants. They once served even more powerful masters—potent wizards known as runelords—and in so doing, commanded entire armies of giants in service to the runelords' empires.

In the eons since these empires collapsed, rune giants have persisted, though to the outside world they're little more than fabled horrors. Rune giants usually dwell in the most remote and rugged of towering mountain ranges, but they can also be found in immense ruins atop lost islands, glacial valleys, or even more remote or magical regions.

Dozens of runes decorate rune giants' striking charcoal flesh. They are towering creatures, averaging at 40 feet in height and weighing 25,000 pounds.

Giants are massive humanoid creatures who live in remote regions throughout the world. They vary widely but are united in their hunger, requiring sustenance of their own element along with the feasts one would expect from such a massive humanoid. Although a simple matter for some giants, more esoteric types find this need a harsh reality. While a massive fistful of ice or snow alongside their meal will satisfy a frost giant, shadow giants hunger for the coagulated shadows of the Netherworld.

effect->Spell Effect: Fly.name: Spell Effect: Fly
effect->Spell Effect: Fly.description:
Granted by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.A2JfEKe6BZcTG1S8]{Fly}

The target can soar through the air, gaining a fly Speed equal to its Speed or 20 feet, whichever is greater.

action->Reactive Strike (Special).name: Reactive Strike (Special)
action->Reactive Strike (Special).description:
The rune giant gains an additional reaction at the beginning of each of their turns that they can use only for a Reactive Strike.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ReactiveStrike]

action->Command Giants.name: Command Giants
action->Command Giants.description: When Czaresia casts a mental spell against another giant, the DC is 41, rather than 37.

action->Demand.name: Demand
action->Demand.description: When a rune giant casts their innate @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.R9xqCBblkS5KE4y7]{Sending} spell, they can also cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.qwlh6aDgi86U3Q7H]{Suggestion} on the target.

action->Flashing Runes.name: Flashing Runes
action->Flashing Runes.description:
Trigger The rune giant uses an arcane ability or casts an arcane spell

Effect The runes on the giant's body flash with magical energy. Each creature within a @Template[emanation|distance:10] must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

action->Invoke Rune.name: Invoke Rune
action->Invoke Rune.description:
The rune giant invokes one of the runes on their body, causing the rune to spray forth a @Template[cone|distance:30] of sparks that deals @Damage[6d12[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in the cone (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic|options:area-effect] save).

The giant can't use Invoke Rune again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Invoke Rune]]{1d4 rounds}.

A glowing copy of the invoked rune appears on a single weapon the giant holds, granting the weapon one effect listed below of the giant's choice. The effect on the weapon lasts for 1 minute. If the giant places a new rune on a weapon, any previously placed rune immediately vanishes, ending its effect.

Rune of Pride (emotion, fear, mental) A creature struck by the weapon becomes convinced they fight an unconquerable foe. The creature must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}. On a critical failure, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} and can't take hostile actions against Czaresia for as long as they remain frightened.

action->Wide Swing.name: Wide Swing
action->Wide Swing.description: Czaresia makes a single mace Strike and compares the attack roll result to the ACs of up to two foes within her reach. This counts as two attacks for Czaresia's multiple attack penalty.

equipment->Dream Hunter's Lodge.name: Dream Hunter's Lodge
equipment->Dream Hunter's Lodge.description:
This miniature hunter's lodge fits comfortably into the palm of one's hand.

Activate–Expand Lodge 2 (concentrate)

Frequency once per day

Effect You set the lodge on the ground, where it expands into a structure 40 feet long, 20 feet wide, and 20 feet high. The lodge is well-built, with a sturdy stone foundation, thick timber walls, and a peaked roof shingled with scraps of bark. The lodge's ground floor contains a dining hall on one end and a sitting area with a hearth surrounded by comfortable chairs on the other. A staircase connects the hall to the lodge's second floor, which consists of four simply furnished bedrooms. The lodge is decorated throughout with taxidermic beasts native to the Dimension of Dreams. If a creature inside the lodge spends 10 minutes studying these trophies, they gain a +3 item bonus to the next skill check they make in the next 24 hours to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} about any creature with the dream trait. Furnishings or decorations removed from the lodge disappear but return to their original locations inside the lodge with the next activation.

You can Dismiss the dream hunter's lodge to return it to its miniature form.

Activate–Oneiric Expedition 10 minutes (concentrate)

Frequency once per day

Requirements The dream hunter's lodge has been expanded and you are inside

Effect Spend 1 Mythic Point. You and all creatures inside the lodge fall into a magical slumber, and the lodge disappears from existence. After 8 hours, the lodge reappears in the Dimension of Dreams (or in the Universe, if the lodge was already in the Dimension of Dreams), as if transported there by an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport} spell. Upon arrival, creatures inside the lodge awaken, fully rested (but this effect does not increase the number of times per day you can do your daily preparations).

equipment->Bands of Force (Greater).name: Bands of Force (Greater)
equipment->Bands of Force (Greater).description:
Decorated with clear gemstones, these thick metal bands spread an inflexible layer of force over your body. The force grants you a +2 item bonus to AC and saving throws, and a maximum Dexterity modifier of +5 as armor. You can affix talismans to the bands as though they were light armor.

Activate—Return Force R (force, manipulate)

Trigger A creature critically misses you with a melee Strike

Effect You Shove the creature using the bands' Athletics modifier of [[/r d20+21]]{+21}.

action->Mythic Resilience (Will).name: Mythic Resilience (Will)
action->Mythic Resilience (Will).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Trinity Star.name: Trinity Star
action->Trinity Star.description: When Dream Aethusa dies, a field of iridescent energy envelops her lifeless body (and her gear) for 10 minutes. During this time, any creature that touches Dream Aethusa's body takes @Damage[9d6[force]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:37|basic] save). After 10 minutes have passed, Aethusa's body rises into the air and is consumed by mythic energy, transforming into the Trinity Star hazard.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Quickened Casting.name: Quickened Casting
action->Quickened Casting.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect If Dream Aethusa's next action is to cast a cantrip or a spell that is 6th-rank or lower, reduce the number of actions to cast it by 1 (minimum 1 action).

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Dream Aethusa regains an expended spell.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Dream Aethusa ends one condition affecting her.

action->Steady Spellcasting.name: Steady Spellcasting
action->Steady Spellcasting.description: If a reaction would disrupt Dream Aethusa's spellcasting action, she attempts a @Check[flat|dc:15]. On a success, the action isn't disrupted.

Elder Shantak.name: Elder Shantak
Elder Shantak.publicNotes:
The imposing shantaks are far more intelligent than their bestial appearance would suggest. They can speak, though their voices sound like glass grinding on stone, and they can't converse in any language besides Aklo.

Shantaks' ability to travel through the gulfs of outer space at supernatural speed allows them to nest on numerous worlds, yet despite this mobility, most shantaks are reluctant to seek out new homes unless faced with no other option. Instead, they roost in discarded ruins or asteroids adrift in space, only emerging and landing upon planets in their chosen stellar system when the urge to feed compels them.

Despite not being native to the Dimension of Dreams, they're commonly found in that realm. Their ability to fly through space affords them swift travel between Leng and more hospitable reaches of the Dreamlands, making them particularly sought after as mounts for those who have business in the far reaches of the dreaming plane.

Convincing a shantak to become a mount is notoriously difficult. They refuse any sort of training, and even if one is convinced to ferry a humanoid on their back, they can be obstinate and fickle. Anyone relying on a shantak mount should have a backup plan ready in case the shantak strands their passenger on an asteroid or strange planet after some disagreement.

Although a shantak is nearly the size of an elephant, many possess irrational fears of certain creatures. In particular, nightgaunts terrify them, but other shantaks have been observed fleeing from harpies and gargoyles. Though these ancestries all share the same trait, shantaks don't fear every type of winged humanoid, which makes the origin of their phobia all the more mysterious. Shantaks on Golarion typically hide themselves away in remote places since several of the creatures they fear appear on the planet in abundance.

action->No Breath.name: No Breath
action->No Breath.description: The elder shantak doesn't breathe and is immune to effects that require breathing (such as inhaled poison).

action->Slippery.name: Slippery
action->Slippery.description: he elder shantak's scales are slimy, granting it a +3 circumstance bonus to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape}. A creature mounted on a shantak takes double the normal circumstance penalty to its Reflex saves (–4 instead of –2 in most cases) while mounted.

action->Flying Strafe.name: Flying Strafe
action->Flying Strafe.description: The elder shantak Flies up to their fly speed and makes two claw Strikes at any point during it's movement. Each Strike must target a different creature. The attacks take the normal multiple attack penalty.

action->Screech.name: Screech
action->Screech.description: The shantak's screech deals @Damage[15d6[sonic]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:50] (@Check[fortitude|dc:33|basic] save). A creature that fails the save is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 3} on a critical failure). The shantak can't use Screech again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Screech]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Share Defenses.name: Share Defenses
action->Share Defenses.description:
Trigger A creature is riding the shantak

Effect The shantak extends their no breath ability and cold resistance to a single creature riding them. They can withdraw this protection as a free action.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.zqgntQXIEbulBgZX]{Effect: Share Defenses}

Elemental Tsunami.name: Elemental Tsunami
Elemental Tsunami.publicNotes:
Elemental tsunamis are huge and destructive, having none of the caring or nurturing aspects of water.

Water elementals can be very destructive, but often not intentionally so; just as water can bring life to mortals in need, its waves can pound shores and rains can flood cities. Water elementals are similarly difficult to predict.

action->Waterbound.name: Waterbound
action->Waterbound.description: When not touching water, the elemental tsunami is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions.

action->Vortex.name: Vortex
action->Vortex.description:
50 feet.

Water in the area that is in the same body of water as the elemental tsunami is difficult terrain for Swimming creatures that don't have the water trait.

action->Drench.name: Drench
action->Drench.description:
The elemental puts out all fires in a @Template[emanation|distance:20].

It extinguishes all non-magical fires automatically and attempts to counteract magical fires ([[/r 1d20+20 #Drench]]{+20} counteract modifier).

action->Mindwarp Ink.name: Mindwarp Ink
action->Mindwarp Ink.description: A creature damaged by an elemental tsunami in area A6 must attempt a @Check[will|dc:31] save to resist being @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} on a critical failure).

action->Surge.name: Surge
action->Surge.description:
The elemental tsunami momentarily expands to fill the area of its vortex. Creatures within the aura take @Damage[(5d12+6)[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[fortitude|dc:31|basic] save. A creature that fails this save is pushed 20 feet.

The elemental tsunami then shrinks to its normal space and can't Surge again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Surge]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Push or Pull 10 feet.name: Push or Pull 10 feet
action->Push or Pull 10 feet.description:
The elemental tsunami can choose whether to push or pull the creature on a succesful hit.

Push 1

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Push]

Pull 1

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Pull]

Endless Realities.name: Endless Realities
Endless Realities.descriptionHazard: A mass of illusions floods the senses of creatures, plunging them into an ever-shifting maze of fluid realties.
Endless Realities.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:38] (legendary) to seize strands of a false reality and tug at them to unravel the surrounding illusions, @Check[arcana|dc:41] to take command of the illusions in a false reality and force them to consume themselves, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (7th-rank; counteract DC 39) to counteract one of the four realities the illusion creates
Endless Realities.routine:
(1 action) The trap shifts from the current reality into a randomly determined one that affects all those lost within the illusion in a different way. The new reality restores 20 Hit Points to itself if it had previously taken damage. Each time a PC succeeds at a check or dispel magic attempt to disable the trap or the current reality is reduced to 0 HP, the current illusory reality vanishes, leaving the PCs in an infinite haze of nothingness save for a three-tailed comet burning in the "sky" above (recognizable as the Trinity Star with a @Check[arcana|dc:25], Nature, Occultism, or Religion check) until the trap takes its next action and randomly determines its new reality from the options that remain. If only one endless reality remains when it's disabled or destroyed, the PCs are returned to the real world and the trap is entirely disabled.

When the endless reality shifts, determine its effects and appearance by randomly selecting from the following (rerolling any results that have already been disabled or destroyed).

Each time a PC critically succeeds at a saving throw to resist a reality's damage, the trap degrades; it's disable DCs and hardness are reduced by 2 with each such critical success. If the trap's hardness is reduced to 0 in this way, the entire trap is disabled at once.

Burning Reality (fire) Additional Immunity fire; Effect The world appears to catch on fire, while legions of burning monsters attack the party. Every PC takes @Damage[10d6[fire]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:34|basic|traits:fire] save).

Frozen Reality (cold) Additional Immunity cold; Effect The world appears to crust over with ice, while armies of frozen ghosts assault the PCs. Every PC takes @Damage[10d6[cold]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:34|basic|traits:cold] save).

Impossible Reality (mental) Additional Immunity physical; Effect The world distorts into a reality of impossible geometry as the PCs feel their own bodies distort to match twisted reflections of unworkable configurations. Every PC takes @Damage[10d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:34|basic|traits:mental] save).

Melting Reality (acid) Additional Immunity acid; Effect The world appears to dissolve away, as slithering oozes swarm out of the surroundings to engulf the PCs. Every PC takes @Damage[10d6[acid]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:34|basic|traits:acid] save).

action->Reality Undone.name: Reality Undone
action->Reality Undone.description:
Trigger A non-follower of Xanderghul attempts to enter the hallway or chambers to the east of this area

Effect A flood of illusions overwhelms in a rush of images and sounds, engulfing the triggering creature and all of their allies within the dawnsilver workshop. Affected creatures must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:34] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} on a critical failure) for 24 hours.

Eron of Jandelay.name: Eron of Jandelay
Eron of Jandelay.publicNotes:
Rarely seen, the erons of Jandelay serve an important function on their apocalyptic home plane. These spindly birdlike creatures tower over the landscape on seven thin legs, covered in ironlike feathers they can hurl with a flick of a wing. Scavengers and collectors, erons dispose of intrusive elements they discover on Jandelay, stashing them in nests for later assortment. Such detritus typically consist of dead adventurers and their gear; an eron won't hesitate to attack a living adventurer, though, and they make little distinction between living or dead "clutter" that doesn't belong.

Remnant Hunters

When an eron of Jandelay finds itself on a doomed world, they often seek out an eclectic list of items, remains, and sometimes even creatures from that planet, almost as if they were picking and choosing their favorite parts of that world before it is no more. Whether the planet is literally on its last days makes no difference to the visiting eron. To these ageless monitors, the actual timing of a world's end is irrelevant to their hunt. Sometimes, valuable scavenged treasures can be discovered amid larger objects or vehicles an eron has been carrying with it via telekinetic haul.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The eron of Jandelay ends one condition affecting them.

action->Frightful Presence.name: Frightful Presence
action->Frightful Presence.description:
90 feet @Check[will|dc:30]

A creature that critically fails a saving throw against an eron's frightful presence is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} as long as they remain frightened.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.FrightfulPresence]

action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude).name: Mythic Resilience (Fortitude)
action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Reactive Beak.name: Reactive Beak
action->Reactive Beak.description: The eron of Jandelay gains 2 reactions each round. It can still use only one reaction per trigger.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Mythic Skill.name: Mythic Skill
action->Mythic Skill.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The eron of Jandelay attempts its next Acrobatics or Thievery skill check with a +4 bonus and is considered to have mythic proficiency for that check.

action->Snatch Prize.name: Snatch Prize
action->Snatch Prize.description: The eron attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.RDXXE7wMrSPCLv5k]{Steal} an object from a creature, using the tips of its immense talons with shocking agility. The object must be 2 Bulk or less. If the creature with the target object is in combat or on guard, the eron can still try to Steal the object if it attempts its Thievery check at mythic proficiency.

action->Unbalancing Rip.name: Unbalancing Rip
action->Unbalancing Rip.description:
Requirements The eron of Jandelay's last action was to damage a Large or smaller creature with a claw Strike

Effect The eron rips at the required creature's flesh. That creature takes @Damage[1d8[persistent,bleed]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of the eron's next turn.

Flawed Memories.name: Flawed Memories
Flawed Memories.descriptionHazard: The murky waters that fill the chamber grant false visions of the past.
Flawed Memories.disable: @Check[crafting|dc:45] (master) to release alchemical reagents to neutralize the ink in the water, @Check[nature|dc:42] (legendary) to manipulate the primal magic in the region and negate the ink's effects, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (8th rank; counteract DC 34) to counteract the magical ink in the water; four success are required to disable it (spells that purify or manipulate water, such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.qXTB7Ec9yYh5JPPV]{Cleanse Cuisine} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.zfn5RqAdF63neqpP]{Control Water}, can affect this hazard as if the caster were using an equal rank dispel magic)
Flawed Memories.reset: The hazard remains disabled until Baolen refills the area with ink (typically once every 4 hours).
Flawed Memories.routine:
(2 actions) On the trap's first action, it attempts a water jet ranged Strike on all creatures outside of the water in this room or on the stairs leading up to area A5. On its second action, the primal magic infusing the waters attempts to seep into the minds of those within it, forcing each creature in the water to attempt a @Check[will|dc:39] save against the following effects.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected

Success The creature takes @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[8d6[mental]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} for 24 hours. While the creature is stupefied, it takes an additional –2 status penalty to checks made to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge}.

Critical Failure As failure, but @Damage[16d6[mental]] damage, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 3}, and the stupefied condition has an unlimited duration.

action->Mindwarp Ink.name: Mindwarp Ink
action->Mindwarp Ink.description:
Trigger A creature moves into the ink-fouled water

Effect The creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:37] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 24 hours (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} for 24 hours on a critical failure). The hazard then rolls initiative.

Gavergash.name: Gavergash
Gavergash.publicNotes:
Long-lived trolls sometimes force their way through the twin distractions of hunger and pain to learn more about the world around them. To manage their regeneration, they learn to cover themselves in crude armor that slowly becomes integrated with the top layer of their flesh. Marked by this armor and aided by their superior wits, these warleaders gather a variety of trolls to serve them in raiding parties.

The warleader presented here is a forest troll, but warleaders can be other types of trolls as well. Many of them are adapted to battle tactics that are best suited to their home environments.

Slavering, cruel, invincible brutes: this is the villager's stock description for the dread monsters known as trolls. The roots of these stories are undoubtedly true. Trolls' flesh endlessly regrows, going so far as to sprout aberrant limbs or additional heads if not pruned, and a bottomless hunger is required to feed such unfettered growth. Even in the process of glutting themselves, however, trolls find opportunities to taunt their prey and inflict petty cruelties.

A troll's ability to survive is so strong that they believe even the smallest scrap of flesh will slowly regenerate into a new form, suffering as all the powers of the land are gathered to revive them. Despite the pain, trolls speak of this unassailable vitality as a blessing from their creator. Few trolls have heard the laughter of demons who claim that creator cursed the trolls and cast them down from lofty heights, binding them so they could never rise again.

Trolls prefer to remain solitary, keeping every scrap of food for themselves. In rare instances, an old and powerful troll comes to lead groups of trolls. Such warleaders possess enough cunning to lead their hordes in devastating raids and massacres, and their presence permanently alters the surrounding ecosystem. This link to their environment is an often misunderstood aspect of trollkind, and grows more acute with a troll's age and power. That's not to say trolls are valorous protectors of nature. They're vicious and territorial, and will blight their own territory forever if it means more to eat for a day.
Gavergash.acDetails: (26 plus all-around vision after Shed Armor)

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Gavergash ends one condition affecting him.

action->Furious Roar.name: Furious Roar
action->Furious Roar.description:
Trigger The troll warleader takes electricity or fire damage

Effect The warleader uses their Primordial Roar and, if they're aware of the damage's source, can Stride toward it. If the warleader has persistent fire damage, they attempt a @Check[flat|dc:15] to remove it.

action->Mythic Resilience (Will).name: Mythic Resilience (Will)
action->Mythic Resilience (Will).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Awaken Totem.name: Awaken Totem
action->Awaken Totem.description:
Requirements Gavergash is adjacent to a totem

Trigger Gavergash used a previous action this round to cast a spell

Effect Gavergash makes a melee Strike against one of the totems and destroys it with a smash from his bec de corbin or claw, funneling the residual magic from his recently cast spell into the totem and causing it to burst in an explosion of distracting color. Any non-troll within a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] of the totem must attempt a @Check[will|dc:39] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and is temporarily immune to Awaken Totem for 24 hours.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the end of Gavergash's next turn.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 minute.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Primordial Roar.name: Primordial Roar
action->Primordial Roar.description:
The troll warleader unleashes a bestial roar. Each non-troll creature in a @Template[emanation|distance:100] must attempt a @Check[will|dc:29] save. The creature is then temporarily immune for 10 minutes.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2}.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3}.

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Gavergash regains an expended spell.

Greedspawn.name: Greedspawn
Greedspawn.publicNotes:
Sinspawn were created by one of seven ancient wizards known collectively as runelords—each of whom embraced and embodied one of seven sins. The first sinspawn was created by the Runelord of Wrath, utilizing techniques that have since gone on to influence fleshwarping practices. It wasn't long before the technique used to create sinspawn fell into the hands of the other runelords, and while each tried their own hand at crafting variants of their own design, today, sinspawn of wrath remain the most numerous and notorious of their kind.

Bearing only a vague resemblance to the humanoids from whose flesh they were formed, sinspawn generally appear horrifically emaciated and have unnaturally long arms and digitigrade legs, each with a trio of stubby, taloned digits. Veins bulge across sinspawn's bodies in sanguine patterns that suspiciously resemble twisted runes, and their flesh is pale and hairless. Their heads are elongated, with slits for a nose, red eyes, and disturbing lower jaws that split in half at the chin, revealing pedipalps that end in tiny, three-fingered hands and framing a long, lolling tongue.

Sinspawn stand 6-1/2 feet tall and typically weigh as much as an emaciated human of their size. They behave in a manner consistent with their associated sin and have physical characteristics that hint at these qualities. For example, greedspawn's veins appear to run with gold, while envyspawn appear even more gaunt than the rest of their kin.
Greedspawn.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic, +4 status to all saves vs. mental

action->Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet.name: Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet
action->Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet.description:
A sinspawn can smell creatures that reflect its sin as the scent ability. The GM determines which creatures are appropriately sinful.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Scent]

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->+4 Status to All Saves vs. Menta.name: +4 Status to All Saves vs. Mental

action->Covetous Claws.name: Covetous Claws
action->Covetous Claws.description: A greedspawn soldier gains a +2 status bonus to attempts made to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm}.

action->Sinful Bite.name: Sinful Bite
action->Sinful Bite.description:
A creature hit by the jaws of a greedspawn soldier must attempt a @Check[will|dc:29] save as it's assailed by avaricious thoughts.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}.

Critical Failure The creature is sickened 2 and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} for 1 minute.

action->Snatch Up.name: Snatch Up
action->Snatch Up.description:
Trigger The greedspawn soldier knocks an item out of a target's grasp with a critical success on a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} attempt

Effect the greedspawn catches the object in a hand before it falls to the ground.

Haunted Forge.name: Haunted Forge
Haunted Forge.hpDetails: to destroy one of the forges (both must be destroyed to disable the haunt completely)
Haunted Forge.descriptionHazard: The rundown furnaces blaze to life, filling with metal and fire, while the wall of hardened lava to the east appears to revert to red hot molten rock.
Haunted Forge.disable: @Check[religion|dc:38] (master) to exorcise the spirits or @Check[intimidation|dc:41] to quell them with furious anger; three total successes are required to disable the haunt
Haunted Forge.routine:
(4 actions) The burning spirits shriek and howl, swooping in and out of the forges to the south, which roar into scorching life. The spirits scoop up gobs of phantasmal molten dawnsilver and hurl them at different targets in the room. Up to four randomly determined creatures are targeted in this way with molten dawnsilver Strikes (the spirits can target any creature in area B5). A single creature may be targeted only once per round, so if there are fewer than four different targets, the haunt's extra actions are lost. The haunt also loses two actions from its routine if one of the two forges are destroyed.

On a critical hit from a molten dawnsilver Strike, the target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round as the molten dawnsilver swiftly cools and encases the target. Molten dawnsilver produced by the haunt vanishes entirely 1 round after it's been thrown.

action->Searing Heat.name: Searing Heat
action->Searing Heat.description:
Trigger A creature comes within 30 feet of either forge

Effect The eastern wall appears to transform into molten lava, and dozens of shrieking human spirits made of fire fly out of the lava to spiral and scorch through the room. Creatures in area B5 must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:34] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[4d6[fire]] damage

Failure The creature takes @Damage[8d6[fire]] damage, @Damage[1d6[persistent,fire]] damage, and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[16d6[fire]] damage, @Damage[2d6[persistent,fire]] damage, and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2}.

Insatiable Bore Worm Swarm.name: Insatiable Bore Worm Swarm
Insatiable Bore Worm Swarm.publicNotes:
A single finger-length bore worm is unpleasant but mostly innocuous. Ten thousand bore worms, on the other hand, pose a formidable threat to even seasoned adventurers. The countless worms form a roiling, rancid mass of acid and pain, capable of delivering a hideous death to any person or beast unable to escape them. Unfortunately for any creature other than a bore worm, most encounters involve swarms.

These Darklands vermin produce corrosive, noxious slime and deliver agonizing bites, whether as a revolting, wriggling swarm of finger-length worms or a single massive, lurching beast. Among Darklands communities, most inhabitants regard bore worms much in the same way surface cultures speak of maggots or cockroaches-with general disdain and revulsion. Children consider catching a single bore worm and using it to torment others a rite of passage, albeit a dangerous one.

The humble bore worm is a small and simple creature, both biologically and magically. These qualities allow it to adapt rapidly to different environments, some of them quite extreme, and also makes it susceptible to magical radiation and experimentation. Many a Darklands apprentice takes their first steps in the school of transmutation by practicing on these worms, while variations-both natural and cultivated-are scattered about beneath Golarion's surface.

action->Painful Devouring.name: Painful Devouring
action->Painful Devouring.description: Each enemy in the swarm's space takes @Damage[8d6[acid]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:38|basic] save). Creatures that fail this save become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} from the swarm's painful bites. On a critical failure, the painful bites cause the creature to become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2}. In either case, the slowed condition persists for 1 round.

Jandelay Tolokand.name: Jandelay Tolokand
Jandelay Tolokand.publicNotes:
Streams run dry. The earth cracks. Green leaves brown and shatter. And the creature walks on.

The faceless, unknowable tolokands wander the land, bringing desolation with every footfall-belching poisonous smoke, blighting plant life, cracking the earth asunder, and even staining the ground with their foul blood. They turn habitable places into wastelands, which has earned tolokands the name "waste walkers."

These walking forces of destruction don't make their motives known. They remain unmoved by any pleas or threats levied at them, and they fight off attacks only so that they can return to their grim business. However, they have one consistent tendency: they travel to environments on the brink. A tolokand appears in a land wracked by famine or a natural disaster to give it the last push into oblivion.

Tolokands are mercifully few in number. Since they appear so rarely, it's unclear whether there are just a few individuals or several dozen. Clearly, more than one exists, though, because their patterned soles are as distinctive as fingerprints. Often, these smoking footprints are all that remain in a blighted land.
Jandelay Tolokand.allSavesBonus: +2 status to all saves vs. primal magic

action->Smoke Vision.name: Smoke Vision
action->Smoke Vision.description: Smoke doesn't impair a tolokand's vision; it ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from smoke.

action->+2 Status to All Saves vs. Prima.name: +2 Status to All Saves vs. Primal Magic

action->Heartless Furnace.name: Heartless Furnace
action->Heartless Furnace.description:
50 feet. @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:37|basic] save).

The poisonous smoke that bellows from a tolokand makes all creatures inside it @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, and all creatures outside the smoke are concealed to creatures within it.

action->Inexorable.name: Inexorable
action->Inexorable.description: The tolokand recovers from the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned} conditions at the end of its turn. It's also immune to penalties to its Speeds and ignores difficult terrain and greater difficult terrain.

action->Toxic Blood.name: Toxic Blood
action->Toxic Blood.description: When a creature scores a critical hit against the tolokand with a piercing or slashing Strike, the tolokand's poisonous, oily blood sprays forth. Any creature within @Template[emanation|distance:5]{5 feet} of the tolokand takes @Damage[3d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:38|basic|options:area-effect] save). Any non-creature plants the blood spills on die.

action->Blighted Footfalls.name: Blighted Footfalls
action->Blighted Footfalls.description: Whenever the tolokand ends a move action during which it moved 30 feet or farther, it automatically casts one of its innate spells as a free action.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The Jandelay tolokand regains an expended spell.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The Jandelay tolokand ends one condition affecting themself.

action->Sudden Destruction.name: Sudden Destruction
action->Sudden Destruction.description:
Requirements The tolokand hasn't cast any of its spontaneous spells this turn

Effect The tolokand casts one of its spontaneous spells, using up the spell slot normally. The tolokand can't cast any further spontaneous spells this turn and can't use this ability again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Sudden Destruction]]{1d4 rounds}.

Javownir.name: Javownir
Javownir.publicNotes: Beings of inscrutable intent and incredible power, dramofirs hail from the Dreamlands and shamble across the multiverse in search of dreams to incorporate into their voluminous robes. Few people on the Material Plane dare trifle with dramofirs and instead treat them with respect, hoping that they'll simply take their chosen victims' dreams and then go away. Often, this is exactly what happens. Every now and then, however, in the process of siphoning an individual's dreams, the dramofir slays their victim without warning or apparent cause.

action->Surreal Anatomy.name: Surreal Anatomy
action->Surreal Anatomy.description: A dramofir has resistance 10 to precision damage and the extra damage from critical hits. If the resistance is greater than the extra damage, it reduces the extra damage to 0 but doesn't reduce the attack's normal damage.

action->Bittersweet Dreams.name: Bittersweet Dreams
action->Bittersweet Dreams.description:
The dramofir swishes their robes in a mesmerizing display that brings the dreams in the robes to life before the viewer's very eyes. Each creature within @Template[emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} must attempt a @Check[will|dc:34] save or be filled with ennui.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and temporarily immune for 24 hours.

Success For 1 round, the creature takes a -1 status penalty to attack rolls, saving throws, and skill checks, and all other emotion effects on it are suppressed.

Failure As success, but the creature is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and the duration is [[/gmr 1d4 #Duration Bittersweet Dreams]]{1d4 rounds}.

Critical Failure As success, but the creature is also slowed 1, the status penalty is -2, and the duration is 1 minute.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.4FginnDcOt4wfedf]{Effect: Bittersweet Dreams}

action->Replace Dream.name: Replace Dream
action->Replace Dream.description:
Requirements The dramofir is adjacent to an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} or sleeping creature

Effect The dramofir licks the creature's forehead, places their hand in the same spot, and siphons the creature's dreams to incorporate into their robes.

If the target is affected by any mental effect altering their dreams, such as an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary-2.Actor.Y9SDbANT1DWI1DKU]{Animate Dream's} curse of endless nightmares or a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Uqj344bezBq3ESdq]{Nightmare} spell, the dramofir attempts to counteract that effect (counteract modifier [[/r 1d20+26 #Counteract]]{+26}). Otherwise, the dramofir plucks a benign dream from the creature, and the target must attempt a @Check[will|dc:36] save.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} until the next time it gets a full night's rest.

Critical Failure As failure, but @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2}, and Javownir casts a 6th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.GP3wewkQXEPrLxYj]{Subconscious Suggestion} on the target (typically suggesting the target seeks out frightening situations so that their dreams become more nightmarish over time).

Kandirvek.name: Kandirvek
Kandirvek.publicNotes:
Fate is a fickle matter on Golarion. Even with prophecy broken on the world, there are ways to look to the immediate future or acquire a vague sense of long-term events. Omen dragons are bound to see the future—nebulous though it might be—at all times. Visions of the future hound them like a quiet song that never stops playing in their minds. While an omen dragon can focus on or ignore the music of fate at any time, the song plays all the same. At a glance, omen dragons resemble other occult dragons in appearance, save for the mirror-like interior membrane of their wings. An omen dragon's wings offer glimpses into the future. These glimpses are cloudy and vague, but generally correct, if only technically. Omen dragons have a natural compulsion to share the futures they see. These dragons have no compunctions about what the visions show and share their knowledge equally with innocent villagers as they do with wicked tyrants.

Dragons come in myriad forms, with many having magical abilities or connections to magic. Some dragons draw greater power from magic than others, allowing them to manifest abilities or alter their physiques with prolonged exposure to magic. These dragons become more powerful as they age and strengthen their connections with their magical origins.
